title: Getting Around Spain — Transport & Travel Guide
content:
To get around in Spain, you can choose from a wide range of transportation options, including an extensive rail network, domestic flights, buses, and city transport systems, as well as renting a car or using ride-hailing services. 

[FACTBOX]
Main International Airport(s): Adolfo Suárez Madrid–Barajas Airport (MAD), Josep Tarradellas Barcelona-El Prat Airport (BCN)
Domestic Air Network: extensive
Rail Network: extensive
Drives On: right
Road Quality: good
Ride-Hailing Apps: Uber, Bolt, Cabify
[/FACTBOX]

[SECTION] Getting There [/SECTION]
Spain has several major international airports, with Adolfo Suárez Madrid–Barajas Airport (MAD) and Josep Tarradellas Barcelona-El Prat Airport (BCN) being the primary entry points for most travelers. These airports offer direct flights to numerous destinations across Europe, the Americas, Africa, and Asia. You can also enter Spain overland from neighboring countries such as France, Portugal, and Andorra, or by sea from Morocco and other Mediterranean countries. 

If you prefer to avoid flying, you can take the train or bus from nearby countries, with several daily services connecting Spain to France, Portugal, and other European nations. Many bus companies, including FlixBus and Eurolines, operate international routes to and from Spain, offering a budget-friendly alternative to flying or taking the train. Additionally, you can also take a ferry from the UK, Italy, or other Mediterranean countries to reach Spain's coastal cities.

[SECTION] Domestic Flights [/SECTION]
Spain has an extensive domestic air network, with several airlines operating flights between major cities and regional airports. **Iberia**, **Vueling**, and **Ryanair** are some of the main domestic airlines, offering frequent flights between destinations like Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia, and the Canary Islands. You can book domestic flights online through the airlines' websites or through travel agencies, with prices starting from around $50-$100 for a one-way ticket, depending on the route and time of year. It's a good idea to book in advance to secure the best prices, especially during peak travel seasons.

[SECTION] Trains & Rail [/SECTION]
Spain has an extensive and modern rail network, with **Renfe** being the primary train operator. The country is connected by high-speed trains, including the **AVE** (Alta Velocidad Española), which links Madrid to other major cities like Barcelona, Valencia, and Seville. You can book train tickets online or at train stations, with prices varying depending on the route and class of service. High-speed trains are a convenient and relatively affordable way to travel between cities, with prices starting from around $60-$100 for a one-way ticket.

[SECTION] Buses & Coaches [/SECTION]
Spain has an extensive network of intercity buses, with several companies operating services between major cities and regional towns. **ALSA** and **FlixBus** are two of the main bus companies, offering frequent services and competitive prices. Bus travel is a budget-friendly option, with prices starting from around $10-$30 for a one-way ticket, depending on the route and time of year. You can book bus tickets online or at bus stations, with many companies offering discounts for advance bookings.

[SECTION] City Transport [/SECTION]
| Mode | Available In | Cost (USD) | Notes |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Metro/Subway | Madrid, Barcelona, Valencia, Bilbao | $2-$3 | Efficient and extensive networks |
| City Bus | Most cities | $1-$2 | Frequent services, affordable prices |
| Taxi | Everywhere | $1.50-$2.50/km | Widely available, but more expensive than public transport |
| Ride-Hailing | Major cities | $5-$10 | Uber, Bolt, and Cabify operate in many cities |
| Bike-Rental | Some cities | $10-$20/day | A great way to explore cities like Barcelona and Seville |

[SECTION] Driving [/SECTION]
- To drive in Spain, you'll need a valid driver's license from your home country or an International Driving Permit (IDP).
- Spain has a well-maintained road network, with many highways and motorways connecting major cities.
- Fuel prices are relatively high in Spain, with gasoline and diesel costing around $1.50-$2.00 per liter.
- Car rental companies like **Europcar**, **Hertz**, and **Avis** operate in Spain, with prices starting from around $40-$60 per day.
- Be aware of toll roads and parking fees, which can add to your expenses.
- Driving in city centers can be challenging, especially in narrow streets and congested areas.

[SECTION] Transport Tips [/SECTION]
- Be mindful of pickpocketing and scams in crowded tourist areas and public transport hubs.
- Use reputable taxi services or ride-hailing apps to avoid overcharging.
- Download transport apps like **Citymapper** or **Google Maps** to navigate cities and plan your routes.
- Consider purchasing a **Spain Rail Pass** for flexible and affordable train travel.
- Don't forget to validate your train ticket before boarding, as fines can be imposed for unvalidated tickets.
- Be prepared for summer heat and crowds in popular tourist destinations.
- Learn some basic Spanish phrases to help you navigate and communicate with locals.
- Always carry a map or guidebook, especially when exploring smaller towns and rural areas.
